question: Give me the goddamn hose! It's okay... Esta bien, esta bien... Come with me... Con mio...
answer: Nice rocket... That took a while.

question: He was awake when I got home. His throat still hurts.
answer: Shit.

question: You're right.
answer: Sorry.

question: No fever.
answer: You better see Dr. Bob. And this time, no opening fire hydrants to play in till he's completely well.

question: Yes, ma'am.
answer: How was your shift?

question: The usual.
answer: Dreamed I did a triple axel in an ice skating championship.

question: Come back and let me see those legs again.
answer: Dr. Bob can squeeze him in at twelve. I have a patient relations meeting at twelve- fifteen. Can you take him?

question: I have a game. But yeah, if we do the handoff at the doctor's.
answer: Yes, he'll be there... Thanks. Five-of in front of Dr. Bob's. Don't be late. Let's get you out, sweetie. Your father just can't keep you dry.

question: Device functioned in front of the Colombian Consulate just as a motorcade full of brass arrived.
answer: Who were the brass, and why were they here?

question: No one's talking yet, but it smells high-level. There were Colombians and Americans in the cars. Three of 'em ate it. Guy on the phone -- -- is one of the survivors. Name's Brandt. C.I.A.
answer: Check the surveillance cameras?

question: We're pulling up the video now.
answer: Where's N.Y.P.D. on this?

question: They know it's ours. They're helping with shoe-leather. We got two dead bystanders, a mother and four-year-old son. The father's over there with a leg wound. Guy's a lieutenant with the New York F.D.
answer: Anybody talk to him yet?

question: Joe Phipps. F.B.I. Counter- terrorism task force.
answer: Mike Brandt.

question: What got this place blown up?
answer: We'll have this discussion somewhere else more secure, after I get your clearance.

question: Hang on.
answer: Dammit...

question: Tell me about it.
answer: How's he holding up?

question: He's shut down... We were hoping they'd keep him here, and he wouldn't have to go home right away, but they're cutting him loose.
answer: Want me to stay at home with him?

question: Rookie's taking the first shift. I'm just getting the schedule at the firehouse rearranged now.
answer: Hey. Got here as fast as I could. I know it sucks... It really sucks... How's the leg?

question: How long before we have a secure computer network?
answer: An hour. They're building it now.

question: What do you got? Do it. Run a total analysis. I want to know if this asshole's right or left-handed. I want everything you can get outta this film. Any helpful information coming outta Colombia?
answer: Gordon Pitt's here. He says he saw a cop at the scene.

question: The cart was stolen from the Central Park Precinct yesterday.
answer: That's him. That's the son of a bitch I bumped into.

question: The bomb's in the cart. We think the bomb was triggered by a cell phone. The guy doesn't have one in his hands here. Did you see a cell phone when you ran into him?
How much time passed between then and the explosion?
answer: ... Seconds... Five, ten...

question: We think maybe he got into the brown Ford. You see him then?
answer: All I cared about was getting to my wife and boy.

question: We might need to call you in again to look at some photos.
answer: ... I touched him... How's that for collateral damage?

question: Mr. Ortiz-Dominguez has agreed not to press charges if you make full restitution.
answer: I've already paid. With my family.

question: Haven't heard from you in a couple days.
answer: Been busy.

question: Yeah. I can see that.
answer: E.L.C. attack platoon... These assholes kill innocent people all the time in Colombia. Thirteen dead in a bus. A market. Twenty-seven dead. A whole family... Anne and Matt didn't mean shit to them. Or him.

question: Hey, we never turned down free beer, and rookie's buying, you believe that? He certified today, he's off probation.
answer: Ronnie couldn't find a fire with both hands.

question: ... Senator, the failure of one operation shouldn't cause your committee to question financing everything else we're doing down there... ... I know it looks bad, and I appreciate your support. Together we'll get it done... Yeah. 'bye. Without his father's money, that asshole'd be keeping bees for a living... What?
answer: Gordy Pitt's on the phone.

question: No.
answer: He's called every day.

question: I don't need it.
answer: Mr. Pitt, Mr. Brandt'll have to get back to you.

question: Tell him not to bother. ... Pleasure.
answer: If you would come with me, please.

question: Is there a problem?
answer: We know who you are, Mr. Pitt.

question: Says so right there in my passport.
answer: We're aware your wife and child were killed in the bombing in New York. We have C.N.N. here, too. It's better for you to visit another country. For your own sake.

question: ... You giving me a choice?
answer: Yes. But not about staying in Colombia. These men will escort you onto whatever flight you wish. It's The Wolf you're after, yes? ... Then I've just done you a bigger favor than you know.

question: Find your fucking leak? All due respect, Noel, it's not likely... And we don't need the whole world looking into what we're doing down here... We find the son-of-a-bitch again, we're bypassing protocols...
answer: Check this out.

question: Jesus Christ...
answer: The man whose wife and son died in New York. One of your units found his passport and credit cards on some gunrunners near Panama. Gunrunners say they left him alive.

question: Habla Ingles?... Que pasa?
answer: There is a military checkpoint up the road. They inspect everyone's papers.

question: Where are all of you going?
answer: We walk around.

question: None of these people have papers?
answer: Some have the wrong papers. Some have none... Alsuelo! Guerrilleros. Vaya! His trouble is over.

question: No! Mina... Mina... Alto. Don't move... Don't move... You'll be okay... You'll be okay. Guerrilla bastards.
answer: No... Military... To stop guerrillas.

question: No! Alto!
answer: Hey, yo, dude, here's a seat, man!

question: No, that's okay --
answer: I was hoping for someone I could communicate with. Only room's at the back near the bano, and I'd advise against it, unless you like poop. Philip Armstrong. Assiniboia, Sasketchewan, Canada. Deerborn Heavy Equipment.

question: ... Gordy Pitt.
answer: Hey, howya doing? I love Germany.

question: Austria. American now.
answer: I love America. Never been to Austria. Where from in America would that be?

question: New York City.
answer: I don't like New York City. Buildings're too big. What kinda work you in?

question: Coffee. I buy beans.
answer: Can't drink caffeine. Makes my stomach do the rumba. I like that commercial guy with the sombrero and the mule, though. Headed upstream, eh? Where to?

question: Caguan.
answer: ... You've never been to Caguan, eh?

question: How do you know?
answer: 'Cause no one in their right mind would ever go back. Caguan's in the guerrilla zone run by the E.L.C. E.L.C. as in 'Extra Loathsome Communists.' They don't care, and they kill. I'm going there myself. But I have a 'get outta jail free' card. E.L.C. travel pass. I can go anywhere I want. Everyone needs equipment fixed. If you don't have one of these, you don't want to be up there, Gordy.

question: Por favor. Con mucho gusto.
answer: Got kids, eh?

question: That little kid and I had a nice, long snooze... We're almost to Mompos. Beautiful country.
answer: It better be. A lotta people're dying for it.

question: Y'know, I haven't noticed one darn body floating downstream this whole trip, have you?
answer: I was thinking... Maybe we could travel together into Caguan. You could show me around.

question: Pass is only good for one person, if that's your idea, which I think it is... Besides, I can't risk traveling around up there in the company of a big gringo with a dumb-ass cover story about coffee beans.
answer: I've got money. I'll buy the pass from you.

question: I've worked too hard for it. And you don't have that kind of money on you.
answer: I'll be getting some life insurance money --

question: It's all cash and carry down here, Gordy. Mompos... You want to have some fun, we'll hook up later. I always schedule a stopover. To sample the local wares and such. Life can be what you make it here on the frontier.
answer: No, thanks.

question: Come with us, please.
answer: I never met a nose I couldn't hang a spoon on. Yahtzee!

question: Come along, Mr. Pitt.
answer: Police catch you trying to steal my hat, you asshole?! Fucking hat thief! Get outta here --

question: Gringos...
answer: That stun gun wasn't cool. Haven't peed my pants in a real long time.

question: That stun gun wasn't cool. Haven't peed my pants in a real long time.
answer: You shouldn't have helped me.

question: Yeah, well, I guess all these assholes down here are just starting on my nerves. So what the hell did you do to land us in here? And don't jerk me around, eh?
answer: The Wolf killed my wife and son in New York.

question: ... Oh, you're that guy, eh? I'm sorry, man... And what, you came down here to even things out? Did you even have a plan?
answer: Yeah. Go to Caguan, find The Wolf and kill him.

question: Don't breathe.
answer: You're not running through the fire, eh?

question: Close your mouth. I'll find a boat to take us upriver.
answer: No. I told you. The pass is only good for one person. And you're too dangerous to travel with. It hasn't been there since we landed. Aw, hell... I was through with this place anyway... I'll call ahead and tell Felix I'm not coming, and you're my replacement. He'll meet you in Caguan and take you to the plantation... What do you know about diesel engines?

question: All the fire trucks are diesels.
answer: You'll have to be Austrian, eh? They hate Americans. Name's gotta change, too, in case they're watching the news. It'll buy you a little time to look around Caguan. But you'll never find The Wolf.

question: Heinrich Beckmann.
answer: Huh?

question: My Austrian name.
answer: Luck got you this far. But up there, luck doesn't make it. I hope you know you're gonna die.

question: Beckmann.
answer: Yeah.

question: Come with me. Armstrong should have called sooner. We don't like changes here... If I didn't need the equipment fixed, I'd send you back. But now we have to see the E.L.C. Supervisor for Caguan.
answer: In Mompos. He was arrested in Ecuador. He got drunk and fooled around with a police officer's wife.

question: We need to fix the equipment. We have delivery deadlines to meet. Si. Gracias. The Supervisor made you my responsibility... You don't go anywhere without me, you understand?
answer: No problemo. The E.L.C. guards your coffee beans?

question: ... Coffee beans? Shit. Armstrong didn't tell you much... The problem's with the diesel generators. The sons-of-bitches keep breaking down. We're using portables to keep production going, but they don't supply enough power to the heat lamps, and we have to dry a lot of... 'coffee beans.' We can fix anything, but these keep dying on us... You'll start now. I'll have tools brought to you. Armstrong's a magician with them. Let's hope you have his skill. Well?
answer: I can't work with these pieces of junk.

question: Junk? These generators cost a fortune.
answer: Then treat them that way.

question: Armstrong always fixes them.
answer: Armstrong wants your money. He makes them work, but he doesn't fix them... To do this right, we gotta order parts from Europe. In the meantime, I can make something temporary. There must be a machine shop in town.

question: ... Yes.
answer: Let's go.

question: Let's get moving.
answer: I'm thirsty. How about you? Want to get something to drink?

question: We have to get back.
answer: I've been working all day out in the sun. I need a drink... nice cold beer? How about it? I saw a bar in town. With the spare parts, I'll have the generators running in two hours... We have time for a couple beers.

question: Okay. Just a beer. Maybe two. This is mine. This is the reason I come here... right, Berta? Me amas? ... She's hot, isn't she?
answer: Yeah. Armstrong said to watch my butt around here. I guess the fucking Americans come down and shoot everyone all the time.

question: Especially now, since the bomb in New York.
answer: Yeah, I heard about it. Who did it?

question: The Wolf, and they'll never catch him.
answer: Ever see him?

question: Once.
answer: Where?

question: If you know too much around here, it can get you killed.
answer: Tell me what doesn't get you killed around here. We'd better get back, huh?

question: ... Shit. It's late.
answer: You're too drunk. I'll drive.

question: One day, I'm going to screw Berta. ... I'll take her to a small restaurant... We'll have lobster and drink lots of wine... I'll get her drunk... We'll drive home... I'll carry her inside... I'll kiss her... And then, I'll screw her in my bed... ... And when I am done screwing her, she'll never want to look at another man again... What the fuck are you doing?!
answer: Hey, easy... What's the problem?

question: You're going the wrong goddamn way!
answer: I am?... Looks different in the dark...

question: Turn around! You drive where I say... Or the Supervisor will have us both shot. It's afternoon. Yesterday, you said it would only take two more hours.
answer: I have this one ready to go.

question: What about the other one?
answer: I just need another part from town, and it's five more minutes.

question: ... Shit. Fine. Let's go. Why're you bringing the tool box?
answer: The old part's in there. I need to match it, and it's all greasy. Berta working today?

question: Ha! Puta!
answer: You as thirsty as I am?

question: No.
answer: We can't stop for one beer?

question: There's beer at the plantation.
answer: There's no Berta at the plantation. I like drinking beer around pretty girls, not a bunch of guys with automatic rifles.

question: To hell with Berta.
answer: What happened? Last night you were in love with her.

question: ... I had a dream... I fed her lobster, got her drunk, and she rejected me for another man. Dreams tell the future.
answer: ... That wasn't a dream, that was the alcohol talking... You saying two men can't go have a beer and look at women's breasts because of pink elephants?... Nothing makes any sense down here. Go ahead and shoot me, and you fix the goddamn generator. Part's in the back.

question: You know I'm your man, baby.
answer: I have to piss. Yo trabajo con Felix. Felix -- -- la cantina. Con Berta.

question: Are you trying to get us both killed?
answer: I went for a walk. I figured you wanted to be alone with Berta.

question: I'll make sure he's on a shorter leash. Shit... You're working all night, Beckmann. That generator gets fixed, and you're out of my hair in the morning.
answer: That make you happy? Where's my money?

question: You'll get it in the morning.
answer: This where Armstrong stays?

question: This is where you stay... A boat will take you down river at seven.
answer: Come on, baby... come on, baby... Just in time...

question: He can't be far. You'll catch --
answer: No! Stop! Alto! Get back!

question: Are you alright?
answer: ... Who are you?

question: My name is Selena.
answer: ... His wife?

question: Yes. I brought you food.
answer: Why feed me? Why not just kill me?

question: Are you so anxious to die?
answer: ... Thanks.

question: The men in jail with you in Mompos... They say you talked to a man from the C.I.A.
answer: I'm not one of them. I'm here for my own reasons.

question: Claudio used to be a teacher. I was a medical aid worker. We met in Guatemala, in an Indian village called Guamaunco. We were married there. Sophia, our daughter was born there. Claudio was kind and loving, and we were happy... We were there four years when the civil war broke out... The guerrillas were all around us, but left us alone... Then they made an attack on the army nearby. The next night, soldiers came to our village. They were led by American 'advisors'... They accused us of helping the rebels. Our women were raped. Our men were tortured. Our homes were burned... We crawled out into the fields, but they threw grenades, and Sophia... ... my baby girl was hit by shrapnel... she bled to death in Claudio's arms. Claudio joined the guerrillas. When that war ended, we moved to the next war, and the next... Each fight has only deepened his hatred. And poisoned his soul. He's unable to love anything anymore...
answer: Why are you still here?

question: Because I know he was a good man, who's been consumed by rage because of what he lost... Just like you.
answer: I'm not like him.

question: Not yet.
answer: He kills innocent people. He's planning to kill more.

question: This is a satellite shot of the Caguan region last night. Here's Caguan town. At 2250, we get a large heat-and- light anomaly consistent with an explosion. This is the explosive area two minutes later. We got a house blown to shit and burning. We got Colombians in cammies, a gringo down, a woman and kid, and some bodies. This guy -- -- is giving all the orders.
answer: ... I don't fucking believe it. That lucky son-of-a-bitch found The Wolf.

question: ... He's paying for it now. A little later, an E.L.C. convoy arrives, and everyone loads up... The convoy travels thirty-two minutes upriver and stops here...
answer: An E.L.C. compound...

question: More like a small village. It's mobile, and it's not just guerrillas -- it's women and kids, too. Here it is by day... Houses, barracks, school for the kids, cooking sheds, H.Q., latrines, gun pits...
answer: They're not just hiding The Wolf.

question: Here it is on the map...
answer: It's well-sited... can't surprise 'em, so you gotta outgun 'em... So that's what we're gonna do.

question: We're gonna hit it?
answer: We're not just gonna hit it, we're gonna wipe if off the globe. Cats, rats, dogs and mice. If it's moving, it's dead.

question: Hitting the whole village could make for a P.R. problem.
answer: I don't care what the Puerto Ricans say. Which part of the word 'war' don't you understand? Our mission down here isn't just about catching The Wolf.

question: ... What about Gordy Pitt?
answer: He was told not to be here... The first choppers'll hit it at 2200.

question: The weather system's intensifying.
answer: What?

question: The storm's gonna be real bad for at least twelve hours. Here's the data. Air ops says it's too heavy for the Blackhawks. Also, Sat-Intel is saying the clouds're too thick, and we're blind.
answer: Got any good news?

question: Yeah. The creeks are rivers around Caguan. Unless The Wolf's a fish, he's not moving... And there's fresh coffee.
answer: Only good thing down here... Put everyone on red till tomorrow night. And then, I don't care if there's a typhoon, I want those fucking rotors turning.

question: I tried to stop him. He's gone back.
answer: The United States? Another bomb?

question: Yes.
answer: Where? Where?

question: ... Washington D.C.
answer: Where in Washington?

question: ... He had pictures of a building...
answer: Which building?

question: I don't know.
answer: We can't let it happen.

question: It's too late. No one can stop him now.
answer: We'd never make it.

question: I got down here from New York...
answer: How many more kids have to die? And for what?

question: ... I'm his wife...
answer: If you don't stop it, you're as much to blame as he is.

question: We're going with you.
answer: How do we get out?

question: The guard is the only one close. When we're past him, we can slip into the jungle. Mauro's waiting for us there. He's on the right... No needless killing. We have to swim.
answer: Go! You okay?

question: Your hired soldiers can't shoot.
answer: Under the water! Uno, dos, tres...

question: Hang on. We just have to keep floating a little bit more... You were shot.
answer: ... I'm okay.

question: We gotta get you outta the river. Esta bien. Esta bien.
answer: He can't hear or speak. He's a war orphan. I adopted him.

question: You're lucky.
answer: I know where we are. There's a secret trail nearby that leads toward Mompos.

question: Can you walk?
answer: It's just my arm.

question: How do you say 'hello'? Yo soy Americano... Gordy Pitt... Gordy Pitt...
answer: F.B.I.'s on the radio. Tell 'em everything you know.

question: They both get asylum. And she needs a medic.
answer: On the plane.

question: What about the asylum?
answer: They'll get it. But she's in my custody till we're done with her.

question: These buildings best match what you described to us.
answer: I don't recognize anything... I saw only parts of the building... I'm sorry.

question: That's okay. We'll keep trying.
answer: I think it's a public place. He said he wanted the people of America to feel the terror. 'Terror is all they understand.' He said it over and over...

question: If we spook him, we don't know what his secondary target'll be.
answer: Please don't kill him.

question: That's him, isn't it?
answer: Yes.

question: ... Let's go through it again, Mr. Pitt.
answer: I've told you all I know.

question: We gotta be sure.
answer: What's that?

question: What's the number on it?
answer: Eleven. She was killed in Guatemala.

question: Number eleven, small seashell with a hole in it... That was found in the getaway car used in the bombing in New York.
answer: Shit...

question: Shit...
answer: We think the bomb was triggered by a cell phone. Did you see a cell phone when you ran into him?

question: No. Where's Selena?!
answer: She went to see her son.

question: You killed them.
answer: One woman, one boy -- they mean nothing next to the thousands who've been slain.

question: They were my family. The killing ends here.
answer: It will never end. Please help me!

question: No. You don't understand.
answer: He's trying to kill me!
